Line 45: Line 45:
;Demographic
;Demographic
{{main|Demographics of Egypt}}
{{main|Demographics of Egypt}}
â
[[File:Egypt.pop.pramid.2005.jpg|thumb|Population pyramid in 2005. Many of those 30 and younger are educated citizens who are having difficulties finding work.]]
+
[[File:Egypt.pop.pramid.2005.jpg|thumb|Population pyramid in 2005. Many of those 30 and younger are highly educated citizens who are having difficulties finding work.]]
The population was 30,083,419 in 1966,<ref name="ReferenceOxford Atlas">The British Oxford economic atlas of the World 4th edition, ISBN 0198941072</ref> which has now grown to roughly 79,000,000 people by 2008.<ref name="popclock">{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname=|title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics â Population Clock (July 2008)|publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg|date=|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Most of this large population live in the limited spaces near the banks of the [[Nile]] River, in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}}, where the only [[arable land]] is found and competing with the need of human habitations. Quantitatively, the emerging [[overpopulation]] crisis thus led to poverty, hygiene, education, and housing issues, as well as a lack of adequate arable land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulane.edu/~rouxbee/kids98/egypt3.html|title=Overpopulation in Egypt: Too Many People, Too Little Space and Resources|publisher=Tulane.edu|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In late 2010 around 40 percent of Egypt's population of just under 80 million lived on the fiscal income equivalent of roughly US$2 per day and a large part of the population relied on subsidised goods.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/>
The population was 30,083,419 in 1966,<ref name="ReferenceOxford Atlas">The British Oxford economic atlas of the World 4th edition, ISBN 0198941072</ref> which has now grown to roughly 79,000,000 people by 2008.<ref name="popclock">{{cite web|url=http://www.msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg/pls/fdl/tst12e?action=&lname=|title=Central Agency for Population Mobilisation and Statistics â Population Clock (July 2008)|publisher=Msrintranet.capmas.gov.eg|date=|accessdate=25 August 2010}}</ref> Most of this large population live in the limited spaces near the banks of the [[Nile]] River, in an area of about {{convert|40000|km2|sp=us}}, where the only [[arable land]] is found and competing with the need of human habitations. Quantitatively, the emerging [[overpopulation]] crisis thus led to poverty, hygiene, education, and housing issues, as well as a lack of adequate arable land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tulane.edu/~rouxbee/kids98/egypt3.html|title=Overpopulation in Egypt: Too Many People, Too Little Space and Resources|publisher=Tulane.edu|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In late 2010 around 40 percent of Egypt's population of just under 80 million lived on the fiscal income equivalent of roughly US$2 per day and a large part of the population relied on subsidised goods.<ref name="AFP-egyptbraces"/>
â
The population growth is recent and created a [[youth bulge]]. According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], the basic problem Egypt has is unemployment driven by a demographic bulge: with the number of new people entering the job force at about 4 percent a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for [[college graduate]]s as it is for people who have gone through elementary school, particularly educated urban youth, who are precisely the people currently seen out in the streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/|title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome|work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
+
The population growth is recent and created a [[Youth bulge|youth bulge]]. According to the [[Peterson Institute for International Economics]], the basic problem Egypt has is unemployment driven by a demographic bulge: with the number of new people entering the job force at about 4 percent a year, unemployment in Egypt is almost 10 times as high for [[college graduate]]s as it is for people who have gone through elementary school, particularly educated urban youth, who are precisely the people currently seen out in the streets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://marketplace.publicradio.org/display/web/2011/02/01/pm-the-long-term-challenges-egypt-must-overcome/|title=The long-term economic challenges Egypt must overcome|work=[[Marketplace (radio program)|Marketplace]]|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo.]]
[[File:Flickr - Daveness 98 - Cityscape in Cairo.jpg|thumb|A poor neighbourhood in Cairo.]]
Line 364: Line 364:
{{quotebox|"So I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution, stipulations of the constitution I know quite well that Egypt, while fighting should try to go out of this juncture, but at the same time the determination of the people is going to help Egypt across this juncture through the perseverance, the honesty of its people, and is going to be above all."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
{{quotebox|"So I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution, stipulations of the constitution I know quite well that Egypt, while fighting should try to go out of this juncture, but at the same time the determination of the people is going to help Egypt across this juncture through the perseverance, the honesty of its people, and is going to be above all."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
â
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak is to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This comes after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggests a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defence Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV says information minister, Anas el-Fiqqi, denies that Mubarak will resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Mubarak says he is transferring his power to his vice president, Omar Suleiman.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech. Some crying or waving their shoes in the air. As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> More than three million people in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace]</ref>Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down, He also called on the military to intervene.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene]</ref>
+
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak is to hand his authorities to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak will speak tonight from his Cairo palace. This comes after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they have stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggests a military coup may be occurring. State TV showed Defence Minster [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and his vice president, Omar Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV says information minister, Anas el-Fiqqi, denies that Mubarak will resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Mubarak says he is transferring his power to his vice president, Omar Suleiman.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA55F03.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> He also said he will request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted it.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA58F81.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech. Some crying or waving their shoes in the air. As far as the transfer of power is concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article is used to transfer powers if the president is "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and does not mean his resignation.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5CEO2.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Mubarak also said he would stay in the country and is "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5JD00.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> More than three million people in Tahrir Square chanted '''Leave! Leave! Leave!''' after Mubarak's speech.<ref>http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman called on the anti-Mubarak protesters to go home.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president]</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace]</ref>Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace<ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110210-719857.html</ref> Mohamed ElBaradei is saying "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and ElBaradei is calling on military intervention.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene]</ref>
Contradicting reports from various media sources around the world state that either Suleiman or Tantawi is expected to take over.<ref> [http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref>
Contradicting reports from various media sources around the world state that either Suleiman or Tantawi is expected to take over.<ref> [http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×],Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref>
Line 438: Line 438:
NGOs also expressed concern about the protests and the ensuing heavy-handed state response. There were also numerous solidarity protests around the world. Many countries also issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens. Even [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating their [[expatriate]] workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
NGOs also expressed concern about the protests and the ensuing heavy-handed state response. There were also numerous solidarity protests around the world. Many countries also issued travel warnings or began evacuating their citizens. Even [[multinational corporation]]s began evacuating their [[expatriate]] workers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/|title=Foreign governments, businesses begin evacuations from Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
{{-}}
{{-}}
  +   +
== Analysis ==
  +
===Foreign relations===
  +
{{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}}
  +   +
Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak"/> After wars with [[Israel]] in 1967 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.<ref>{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date =10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate = 28 January 2011}}</ref> Many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the [[West]].{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=this is based on opinion essay (by juan cole). needs clear wording and proper disclosure that it is cole speaking and not wikipedia with OR.}}<ref name="cole">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan ([[essay]])|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular amongst the general Egyptian public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref>
  +   +
===Military===
  +
{{main|Military of Egypt}}
  +   +
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than police, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of systemic corruption and illegitimate violence. All four Egyptian presidents since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the defense minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], chief of staff of the armed forces.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
  +   +
===Alexandria church bombing===
  +
{{main|2011 Alexandria bombing}}
  +   +
Early on New Year's Day 2011 a bomb exploded in front of a church in Alexandria, killing 23 [[Copts|Coptic]] Christians. Egyptian officials said "foreign elements" were behind the attack.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Church Blast Death Toll Rises to 23|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE7010M020110104|work=[[Reuters]]|date=4 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Some Copts accused the Egyptian government of negligence,<ref name="Clashes Grow">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news| last= Slackman| first= Michael| url= http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/04/world/middleeast/04egypt.html| title= Clashes Grow as Egyptians Remain Angry After an Attack|work=[[The New York Times]] | date= 4 January 2011| accessdate= }}</ref> and following the attacks many Christians protested in the streets, with Muslims later joining the protests. After clashing with the police, protesters in Alexandria and Cairo shouted slogans denouncing Mubarak's rule<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Media Warn of Civil War after Bombing|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gM4ojQSkgen45AIWUkmRXYIsEFwA|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher =''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[Google News]]'')|date=2 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{Cite news|author=Stack, Liam; Kirkpatrick, David D.|title=Egypt Orders Tighter Security After Church Bombing|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html?partner=rss&emc=rss|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Jouini|first=Hassen|title=Muslims Protect Churches|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/Muslims+protect+churches/4078614/story.html|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[National Post]]|date=8 January 2011}}</ref> in support of unity of Christians and Muslims. Their sense of being let down by national security forces has been cited as one of the first signs of the 25 January uprising.<ref>Interview. "Vivian Ibrahim of the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]] at the [[University of London]]". ''[[BBC News]]'' 3 February 2011; 12:55 UTC.</ref>
  +   +
On February 7, a complaint was filed against Habib al-Adly, the Interior Minister until Mubarak's dissolution of the government during the early days of the protests, accusing him of having directed the attack.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/tuesday%E2%80%99s-papers-funeral-martyr-journalist-ghoneim-release-al-adli-under-investigation|title=Tuesdayâs papers: Funeral for martyr journalist, Ghoneim release, al-Adli under investigation|author=Heba Helmy|date=February 8, 2011|publisher-Al Masry Al Youm}}</ref>
